pr_title: Make query result HTTP response compression configurable

timeline.message:
Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.

Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.

Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.

Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.

timeline.bodyText: Can we instead use compressionEnabled? Disabled would incur one more flip in mind :)
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText: The phrasing is a little weird, but the mechanism here doesn't actually let you force compression- only disable compression. Same thing with the server side logic. Default negotiation happens inside of jetty around the client Accept-Encoding header and server's chosen mime-type and Content-Encoding headers.
replies.author: pettyjamesm

replies.bodyText: I see. But we could probably just flip the boolean when it is used? I'm just worried this might be error-prone.
replies.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText: In general I’m worried about the impression that “enabled” will give. To me, that sounds like the client has ultimate control of the decision when in fact, they do not. The client only as the option to opt-out of compression.
replies.author: pettyjamesm

timeline.bodyText: I understand that we are trying to reduce duplicate code, but passing compressionEnabled  to withCompressionEnabled is a bit weird and sounds like this should be done outside.
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

timeline.message:
Make query result HTTP compression client configurable

By default, presto will GZIP query result JSON payloads sent to the
client. However, especially when the client is connected to the
coordinator over localhost, the added overhead of compressing the
response and then uncompressing it on the client is a losing
proposition.

For queries that are bound only by result processing throughput (eg:
SELECT * FROM <large table>) execution time can reduced by 20-50%
when submitted over a localhost connection with compression disabled.

Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.

Make query result HTTP compression server configurable

Allows configuring HTTP response compression for the query results
endpoints at the server level, regardless of client configuration.
